sections.name: Overview
contents: Lair of the Minotaur is a maze-solving game with a tinge of horror. I was responsible for scripting and assembly of the project, while Cathryn Grange directed the art. Alec Summers directed our design choices.

The player is cast as a young girl who must navigate a series of mazes using only her lantern and her wits to survive the horrors within. The player must avoid spiders, bats, and, of course, a Minotaur.
You can read more about it here.

sections.name: Player Mechanics
contents: In order to imbue the player with a feeling of despair, there is no means of directly combating the enemies that populate the dungeon.
Player health is represented via the radius of light emitted from their lantern.
The color of light emitted impacts enemy visibility and also acts as extra player lives.
To emulate a "breadcrumb trail" system, the player can light torches that have been distributed throughout the maze. To help encourage this action, Torch lighting also restores player health.

sections.name: Environmental Mechanics
contents: We opted to randomly generate mazes in order to provide players with a different experience each time.
The maze is composed of three branch types- the critical path, spider nests, and bat caverns.
Initially, each enemy spawn was confined to its branch type. However, after initial playtesting, bats were distributed throughout the dungeon in order to make the critical path more exciting.
Each branch type ends in a room that houses its key monster type.
